intro: Ageratum febrifugum, commonly known as feverfew, is a flowering plant native to the Americas. It is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and clusters of small, daisy-like flowers that range in color from white to pale yellow. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has a long history of use in traditional medicine. The essential oils extracted from its leaves contain compounds like parthenolide, which have been studied for their potential therapeutic properties.
